name.text: Differentiation: Finding the Derivative of an Expression

questiontext.text:
Find \(\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx}\) for \({@expr@}\)

Step 1: Differentiate both sides with respect to \(x\), yields to.


( [[input:ans1]] ) \( \cdot \displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} +\) [[input:ans1s]] [[feedback:prt1]]
[[validation:ans1]] [[validation:ans1s]]

Step 2: The final step is to deduce \(\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx}\).


\(\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx}=\) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:prt2]]

generalfeedback.text:
Worked solution

Recall the following derivations of functions

Functions Derivative formulas
\( \sqrt{f} \) \(\displaystyle \frac{f'}{2f}\)
\( \ln f\) \( \displaystyle \frac{f'}{f} \)
\((f + g)' \) \(f' + g'\)
\(\displaystyle \frac{f}{g} \) \(\displaystyle \frac{f'g - g'f}{g^2} \)
\(\alpha f\) \(\alpha f'\)

Let's find \(\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx}\) for \({@expr@}\)

The first step is to differentiate both sides with respect to \(x\).

Remember that the key to this is to always think of \(y\) as a function of \(x\), or \(y=y(x)\)

\( \begin{align} \displaystyle \frac{d}{dx} ({@aa*y^bb+cc*x^dd@}) & = & \displaystyle \frac{d}{dx} ({@ee*x^gg, simp@}) \\ \displaystyle \frac{d}{dy} ({@aa*y^bb@}) \cdot \displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} + \displaystyle \frac{d}{dx} ({@cc*x^dd@}) & = & \displaystyle \frac{d}{dx} ({@ee*x^gg, simp@})\\ \displaystyle {@diff(aa*y^bb,y)@} \cdot \displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} + {@diff(cc*x^dd,x)@} & = & \displaystyle {@diff(ee*x^gg,x)@} \\ \displaystyle {@diff(aa*y^bb,y)@} \cdot \displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} & = & \displaystyle {@diff(ee*x^gg-cc*x^dd,x)@} \\ \displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} & = & \displaystyle {@ta_2@}\\ \end{align} \)

questionnote.text:
\(\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx}\) for \({@expr@}\)

Differenting with respect to \(x\), yields to.


\( {@ta_1@} \cdot \displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} +{@ta_1s@} \)

Deducing \(\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx}\).


\(\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx}={@ta_2@} \)

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

truefeedback.text: You seem to have differentiated with respect to y instead of x which should not be the case
You seem to have differentiated with respect to y instead of x which should not be the case
You seem to have added a constant of integration which should not be the case, Remember we are differentiating not integrating.
